sp.p: Hang him fusty satyr, he smells all goat; he carries a ram, under his armholes, the slave: I am the worse when I see him. Did not Minos impart?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes, here are twenty drachmas, he did convey.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Well said, keep them, we will share anon; come, little Minos.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Faith, Captain, I will be bold to show you a mistress of mine, a jeweller's wife, a gallant, as we go along.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: There spoke my Genius. Minos, some of thy eryngoes, little Minos; send: come hither, Parnassvs, I must have thee familiar with my little locust, here, it is a good vermin, they say. See, here is Horace, and old Trebativs, the great lawyer, in his company; let us avoid him, now: He is too well seconded.

div2.stage:
Act III. Scene V.
Horace, Trebativs.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: There are, to whom I seem excessive sour;
And past a satire's law, to extend my power:
Others, that think whatever I have writ
Wants pith, and matter to eternize it;
And that they could, in one days light, disclose
A thousand verses, such as I compose.
What shall I do, Trebativs? say.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Surcease.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: And shall my Muse admit no more increase?

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: So I advise.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: An ill death let me die.
If it were not best; but sleep avoids mine eye:
And I use these, lest nights should tedious seem.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Rather, contend to sleep, and live like them,
That holding golden sleep in special price,
Rubbed with sweet oils, swim silver Tyber thrice,
And every evening, with neat wine steeped be:
Or, if such love of writing ravish thee,
Then dare to sing unconquered Caesar's deeds;
Who cheers such actions, with abundant meeds.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: That, father, I desire; but when I try,
I feele defects in every faculty:
Nor is it a labour fit for every pen,
To paint the horrid troops of armed men;
The lances burst, in Gallia's slaughtered forces;
Or wounded Parthians, tumbled from their horses:
Great Caesar's wars cannot be fought with words.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Yet, what his virtue in his peace affords,
His fortitude, and justice thou canst show;
As wise Lvcilivs, honoured Scipio.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Of that, my powers shall suffer no neglect,
When such sleight labours may aspire respect:
But, if I watch not a most chosen time,
The humble words of Flaccvs cannot clime
The attentive ear of Caesar; nor must I
With less observance shun gross flattery:
For he, reposed safe in his own merit,
Spurns back the glosses of a fawning spirit.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: But, how much better would such accents sound,
Than, with a sad, and serious verse to wound
Pantolabvs, railing in his saucy jests?
Or Nomentanvs spent in riotous feasts?
"In satires, each man (though untouched) complains
"As he were hurt; and hates such biting strains.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What shall I do? Milonivs shakes his heels
In ceaseless dances, when his brain once feels
The stirring fervor of the wine ascend;
And that his eyes false number apprehend.
Castor his horse; Pollvx loves handy fights:
Thousand heads, a thousand choice delights.
My pleasure is in feet, my words to close,
As, both our better, old Lvcilivs does:
He, as his trusty friends, his books did trust
With all his secrets; nor, in things unjust,
Or actions lawful, ran to other men:
So, that the old man's life, described was seen
As in a votive table in his lines;
And to his steps my Genius inclines,
Lucanian, or Apulian, I not whether;
For the Venusian colony ploughs either:
Sent thither, when the Sabines were forced thence
(As old fame sings) to give the place defence
Against such, as seeing it empty, might make rode
Upon the empire; or there fix abode:
Whether the Apulian borderer it were,
Or the Lucanian violence they fear.
But this my style no living man shall touch,
If first I be not forced by base reproach;
But, like a sheathed sword, it shall defend
My innocent life; for, why should I contend
To draw it out, when no malicious thief
Robs my good name, the treasure of my life?
O Ivpiter, let it with rust be eaten,
Before it touch, or insolently threaten
The life of any with the least disease;
So much I love, and woe a general peace.
But, he that wrongs me (better, I proclaim,
He never had assayed to touch my fame.)
For he shall weep, and walk with every tongue
Throughout the city, infamously song.
Servivs, the Praetor, threats the laws, and urn,
If any at his deeds repine or spurn;
The witch, Canidia, that Albvcivs got,
Denounceth witch-craft, where she loveth not:
Thvrivs, the judge, doth thunder worlds of ill,
To such, as strive with his judicial will;
"All men affright their foes in what they may,
"Nature commands it, and men must obey.
Observe with me; "The wolf his tooth doth use:
"The bull his horn. And, who doth this infuse,
"But nature? There is luxurious Scaeva; Trust
His long-lived mother with him; His so just
And scrupulous right hand no mischief will;
No more, than with his heel a wolf will kill,
Or Ox with jaw: Marry, let him alone
With tempered poison to remove the crone.
But, briefly, if to age I destined be,
Or that quick deaths black wings environ me;
If rich, or poor; at Rome; or fate command
I shall be banished to some other land;
What hue soever, my whole state shall bear,
I will write satires still, in spite of fear.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Horace; I fear, thou drawest no lasting breath:
And that some great man's friend will be thy death.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What? when the man that first did satirise,
Durst pull the skin over the ears of vice;
And make, who stood in outward fashion clear,
Give place, as foul within; shall I forbear?
Did Laelivs, or the man, so great with fame,
That from sacked Carthage fetched his worthy name,
Storm, that Lvcilivs did Metellvs pierce?
Or bury Lvpvs quick, in famous verse?
Rulers, and subjects, by whole tribes he checked;
But virtue, and her friends did still protect:
And when from sight, or from the judgment seat,
The virtuous Scipio, and wise Laelivs met,
Unbraced, with him in all light sports, they shared;
Till, their most frugal suppers were prepared.
Whatever I am, though both for wealth, and wit;
Beneath Lvcilivs, I am pleased to sit,
Yet, envy (spite of her empoisoned breast)
Shall say, I lived in grace here, with the best;
And, seeking in weak trash to make her wound,
Shall find me solid, and her teeth unsound:
Unless, learned Trebativs censure disagree.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: No, Horace, I of force must yield to thee;
Only, take heed, as being advised by me,
Lest thou incur some danger: Better pause
Than rue thy ignorance of the sacred laws;
There is justice, and great action may be sued
Against such, as wrong men's fames with verses lewd.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Aye, with lewd verses; such as libels be,
And aimed at persons of good quality.
I reverence and adore that just decree:
But if they shall be sharp, yet modest rimes
That spare men's persons, and but tax their crimes,
Such, shall in open court, find currant pass;
Were Caesar judge, and with the makers grace.

sp.speaker: Treb.
sp.l: Nay, I will add more; if thou thyself being clear,
Shalt tax in person a man, fit to bear
Shame, and reproach; his suit shall quickly be
Dissolved in laughter, and thou thence sit free.

div2.stage:
Act IIII.
Scene I.
Chloe, Cytheris.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: But, sweet lady, say: am I well enough attired for the court, in sadness?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Well enough? excellent well, sweet Mistress Chloe, this straight-bodied city attire (I can tell you) will stir a courtiers blood, more, than the finest loose sacks the ladies use to be put in; and then you are as well jewelled as any of them, your ruff, and linen about you, is much more pure than theirs: And for your beauty, I can tell you, there is many of them would defy the painter, if they could change with you. Marry, the worst is, you must look to be envied, and endure a few court-frumps for it.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: O Iove, Madam, I shall buy them too cheap! Give me my muff, and my dog there. And will the ladies be anything familiar with me, think you?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: O Ivno! why, you shall see them flock about you with their puff wings, and ask you, where you bought your lawn? and what you paid for it? who starches you? and entreat you to help them to some pure laundresses, out of the city.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: O Cvpid! give me my fan, and my masque too: And will the lords, and the poets there, use one well too, lady?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Doubt not of that: you shall have kisses from them, go pit-pat, pit-pat, pit-pat, upon your lips, as thick as stones out of slings, at the assault of a city. And then your ears will be so furred with the breath of their complements, that you cannot catch cold of your head (if you would) in three winters after.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Thank you, sweet lady. O heaven! And how must one behave herself amongst them? you know all.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Faith impudently enough, mistress Chloe, and well enough. Carry not too much underthought betwixt yourself and them; nor your city mannerly word (forsooth) use it not too often in any case; but plain, Aye, Madam; and, No, Madam: Nor never say, your Lordship, nor your Honour; but, you, and you my Lord, and my Lady: the other, they count too simple, and minsitive. And though they desire to kiss heaven with their titles, yet they will count them fools that give them too humbly.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p:
O intolerable, Ivpiter! By my troth, lady, I would not for a world, but you had lain in my house: and i'faith you shall not pay a
farthing, for your board, nor your chambers.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: O, sweet Mistress Chloe!

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I'faith, you shall not lady, nay, good lady, do not offer it.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene II.
Cor. Gallvs, Tibvllvs, Cytheris, Chloe.

sp.speaker: Cor. Gall.
sp.p: Come, where be these ladies? By your leave, bright stars, this gentleman and I are come to man you to court: where your late kind entertainment is now to be requited with a heavenly banquet.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: A heavenly banquet, Gallus?

sp.speaker: Cor. Gall.
sp.p: No less, my dear, Cytheris.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: That were not strange, lady, if the epithet were only given for the company invited thither; yourself, and this fair gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Are we invited to court, sir?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: You are, lady, by the great Princess, Ivlia: who longs to greet you with any favours, that may worthily make you an often courtier.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: In sincerity, I thank her, sir. You have a coach? have you not?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: The Princess hath sent her own, lady.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: O Venus! that is well: I do long to ride in a coach most vehemently.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: But, sweet Gallvs, pray you, resolve me, why you give that heavenly praise, to this earthly banquet?

sp.speaker: Cor. Gall.
sp.p: Because (Cytheris) it must be celebrated by the heavenly powers: All the Gods, and Goddesses will be there; to two of which, you two must be exalted.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: A pretty fiction in truth.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: A fiction indeed, Chloe, and fit, for the sit of a poet.

sp.speaker: Cor. Gall.
sp.p: Why, Cytheris, may not poets (from whose divine spirits, all the honours of the gods have been deduced) entreat so much honour of the gods, to have their divine presence at a poetical banquet?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Suppose that no fiction: yet, where are your abilities to make us two goddesses, at your feast?

sp.speaker: Cor. Gall.
sp.p: Who knows not (Cytheris) that the sacred breath of a true poet, can blow any virtuous humanity, up to deity?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p:
To tell you the female truth (which is the simple truth) ladies; and to show that poets (in spite of the world) are able to deify themselves: At this banquet, to which you are invited, we intend to assume the figures of the Gods; and to give our several Loves the forms of Goddesses. Ovid will be Ivpiter; the Princess Ivlia, Ivno; Gallvs here Apollo; you Cytheris, Pallas; I will be Bacchvs; and my Love Plavtia, Ceres: And to install you, and your husband,
fair Chloe, in honours, equal with ours; you shall be a Goddess, and your husband a God.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: A God? O my god!

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: A God, but a lame God, lady: for he shall be Vulcan, and you Venvs. And this will make our banquet no less than heavenly.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: In sincerity, it will be sugared. Good Iove, what a pretty foolish thing it is to be a poet! But hark you, sweet Cytheris; could they not possibly leave out my husband? methinks, a bodies husband does not so well at Court: A bodies friend, or so---but husband, it is like your clog to your marmoset, for all the world, and the heavens.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Tut, never fear, Chloe: your husband will be left without in the lobby, or the great chamber, when you shall be put in, in the closet, by this lord, and by that lady.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Nay, then I am certified: he shall go.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene III.
Gallvs, Horace, Tibvllvs, Albivs, Crispinvs, Tvcca, Demetrivs, Cytheris, Chloe.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Horace! Welcome.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Gentlemen, hear you the news?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: What news, my Qvintvs?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Our melancholic friend, Propertivs,
Hath closed himself, up, in his Cynthias tomb;
And will by no entreaties be drawn thence.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Nay, good master Crispinvs, pray you, bring near the gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Crispinvs? Hide me, good Gallvs: Tibvllvs, shelter me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Make your approach, sweet Captain.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: What means this, Horace?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I am surprised again, farewell.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Stay, Horace.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: What, and be tired on, by yond vulture? No:
Phoebvs defend me. Tibv, 'Slight! I hold my life,
This same is he met him in holy street.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Troth, it is like enough. This act of Propertivs relisheth very strange, with me.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: By thy leave, my neat scoundrel: what, is this the mad boy you talked on?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Aye: this is master Albivs, Captain.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, Agamemnon; we hear abroad, thou art the Hector of citizens: what sayst thou? are we welcome to thee, noble Neoptolemvs?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Welcome, Captain? by Iove, and all the Gods in the capitoll---

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: No more, we conceive thee. Which of these is thy wedlock, Menelavs? thy Hellen? thy Lvcrece? that we may do her honour; mad boy?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: She in the little fine dressing, sir, is my Mistress.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: For fault of a better, sir.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: A better, profane rascal? I cry thee mercy (my good scroll) was it thou?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: No harm, Captain.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: She is a Venvs, a Vesta, a Melpomene: Come hither, Penelope; what is thy name, Iris?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: My name is Chloe, sir; I am a gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Thou art in merit to be an empress (Chloe) for an eye, and a lip; thou hast an emperors nose: kiss me again: it is a virtuous punk, So. Before Iove, the gods were a sort of gollings, when they suffered so sweet a breath, to perfume the bed of a stinkard: thou hadst ill fortune, Thisbe; the fates were infatuate; they were, punk; they were.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: That is sure, sir: let me crave your name, I pray you, sir.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: I am known by the name of Captain Tvcca, punk; the noble Roman, punk: a gentleman, and a commander, punk.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: In good time: a gentleman, and a commander? that is as good as a poet, methinks.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: A pretty instrument! It is my cousin Cytheris viol, this: is it not?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Nay, play cousin, it wants but such a voice, and hand, to grace it, as yours is.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Alas, cousin, you are merrily inspired.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Pray you play, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes, cousin: you know, I do not hate you.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: A most subtle wench! How she hath baited him with a viol yonder, for a song!

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Cousin, pray you call mistress Chloe; she shall hear an essay of my poetry.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: I will call her. Come hither, cockatrice: here is one, will set thee up, my sweet punk; set thee up.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Are you a poet, so soon, sir?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Wife: mum.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: Love is blind, and a wanton;
In the whole world, there is scant
one such another:
No, not his Mother.
He hath plucked her doves, and sparrows,
To feather his sharpe arrows,
And alone prevaileth,
Whilst sick Venvs waileth.
But if Cypris once recover
The wag; it shall behove her
To look better to him:
Or she will undo him.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: O, most odoriferous music!

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: A, ha! stinkard. Another Orphevs, you slave, another Orphevs! an Arion, riding on the back of a dolphin, rascal!

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Have you a copy of this ditty, sir?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Master Albivs has.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Aye, but in truth, they are my wives verses; I must not show them.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Show them, bankrupt, show them; they have salt in them, and will brooke the air, stinkard.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How? to his bright mistress, Canidia?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Aye, sir, that is but a borrowed name; as Ovids Corinna, or Propertivs his Cynthia, or your Nemesis, or Delia, Tibvllvs.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: It is the name of Horace his witch, as I remember.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Why? the ditty is all borrowed; it is Horaces: hang him plagiary.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: How? he borrow of Horace? he shall pawn himself to ten brokers, first. Do you hear, Poetasters? I know you to be men of worship---He shall write with Horace, for a talent: and let Mecoenas, and his whole college of critics take his part: thou shalt do it, young Phoebvs: thou shalt, Phaeton; thou shalt.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: Alas, sir, Horace! he is a mere sponge; nothing but humours, and observation, he goes up and down sucking from every society, and when he comes home, squeezes himself dry again. I know him, I.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Thou sayst true, my poor poetical Fury, he will pen all he knows. A sharpe thorny toothed satirical rascal, fly him; he carries hey in his horn: he will sooner lose his best friend, than his least jest. What he once drops upon paper, against a man, lives eternally to upbraid him in the mouth of every slave tankard bearer, or water-man; not a bawd, or a boy that comes from the bake-house, but shall point at him: it is all dog, and scorpion; he carries poison in his teeth, and a sting in his tail. Faugh, body of Iove! I will have the slave whipped one of these days for his satires, and his humours, by one cashiered clerk, or another.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: We will undertake him, Captain.

sp.speaker: Deme.
Tvcc.
sp.p:
Say no more then, but do it; it is the only way to get thee a new suit; sting him, my little neufts; I will give you instructions: I will be
your intelligencer, we will all join, and hang upon him like so many horse-leaches, the players and all. We shall sup together, soon; and then we will conspire, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: O, that Horace had stayed still, here.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: So would not I: for both these would have turned Pythagoreans, then.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: What, mute?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Aye, as fishes i'faith: come, ladies, shall we go?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: We await you, sir. But mistress Chloe asks, if you have not a god to spare, for this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Who, Captain Tvcca?

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Aye; he.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Yes, if we can invite him along, he shall be Mars.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Has Mars anything to do with Venvs?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: O, most of all, lady.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Nay, then, I pray let him be invited: and what shall Crispinvs be?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Mercvry, mistress Chloe.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Mercvry? that is a Poet? is it?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: No, lady; but somewhat inclining that way: he is a Herald at arms.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: A Herald at arms? good: and Mercvry? pretty: he has to do with Venvs, too?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: A little, with her face, lady; or so.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: It is very well; pray let us go, I long to be at it.

sp.speaker: Cyth.
sp.p: Gentlemen, shall we pray your companies along?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: You shall not only pray, but prevail, lady. Come, sweet Captain.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Yes, I follow: but thou must not talk of this now, my little bankrupt.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Captain, look here: mum.

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: I will go write, sir.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Do, do, stay: there is a drachma, to purchase ginger-bread, for thy muse.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene IIII.
Lvpvs, Histrio, Lictor, Minos, Mecoenas, Horace.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Come, let us talk, here; here we may be private: shut the door, Lictor. You are a player, you say.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: , if it please your worship.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Good: and how are you able to give this intelligence?

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Marry, sir, they directed a letter to me, and my fellow-sharers.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p:
Speak lower, you are not now in your theatre, Stager: my
sword, knave. They directed a letter to you, and your fellow-sharers; forward.

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Yes, sir; to hire some of our properties; as a sceptre, and a crown, for Iove; and a caduceus for Mercvry: and a petasus ---

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Caduceus? and petasus? Let me see your letter. This is a conjuration; a conspiracy, this. Quickly, on with my buskins: I will act a tragedy, i'faith. Will nothing but our gods serve these poets to profane? dispatch. Player, I thank thee. The Emperor shall take knowledge of thy good service. Who is there now? Look, knave. A crown, and a sceptre? this is good: rebellion, now?

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: It is your pothecary, sir, master Minos.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p:
What tellest thou me of apothecaries, knave? Tell him; I have affairs of state, in hand; I can talk to no apothecaries, now. Heart of me! Stay the pothecary there.
You shall see, I have fished out a cunning piece of plot now: They have had some intelligence, that their project is discovered, and now have they dealt with my pothecary, to poison me; it is so; knowing, that I meant to take physic today: As sure as death, it is there. Ivpiter, I thank thee, that thou hast yet made me so much of a politician. You are welcome, sir; take the potion from him there; I have an antidote more than you wote off, sir; throw it on the ground there: So. Now fetch in the dog; And yet we cannot tarry to try experiments, now: arrest him, you shall go with me, sir; I will tickle you, apothecary; I will give you a glister, i'faith. Have I the letter? Aye: it is here. Come, your fasces, Lictors: The half pikes, and the halberds, take them down from the lares, there. Player, assist me.

sp.speaker: Mecœ.
sp.p: Whither now, Asinivs Lvpvs, with this armoury?

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: I cannot talk now; I charge you, assist me: Treason, treason.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: How? treason?

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Aye: if you love the Emperor, and the state, follow me.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene V.
Ovid, Ivlia, Gallvs, Cytheris, Tibvllvs, Plavtia, Albivs, Chloe, Tvcca, Crispinvs, Hermogenes, Pyrgvs.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Gods, and Goddesses, take your several seats. Now, Mercvry, move your caduceus, and in Ivpiters name command silence.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: In the name of Ivpiter; silence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: The crier of the court hath too clarified a voice.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Peace, Momus.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p:
O, he is the God of reprehension; let him alone. It is his office. Mercvry, go forward, and proclaim after Phoebvs, our high
pleasure, to all the Deities that shall partake this high banquet.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes, sir.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: The great God, Ivpiter,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: The great, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Of his licentious goodness,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Of his, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Willing to make this feast, no fast

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Willing, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: From any manner of pleasure;

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: From any, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Nor to bind any God or Goddess,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Nor to, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: To be anything the more god or goddess for their names;

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: To be, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: He gives them all free licence,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: He gives, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: To speak no wiser, than persons of baser titles;

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: To speak, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And to be nothing better, than common men, or women.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: And to, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And therefore no God

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: And there, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Shall need to keep himself more strictly to his Goddess,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Shall need, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Than any man does to his wife.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Than any, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Nor any Goddess

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Nor any, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Shall need to keep herself more strictly to her God,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Shall need, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Than any woman does to her husband.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Than any, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: But, since it is no part of wisdom,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: But, since, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: In these days, to come into bonds;

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: In these, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: It shall be lawful for every lover,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: It shall, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: To break loving oaths,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: To break, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: To change their lovers, and make love to others,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: To change, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: As the heat of every ones blood,

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: As the, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And the spirit of our nectar shall inspire.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: And the, &c.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: And Ivpiter, save Ivpiter.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: And Ivpi. &c.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: So: now we may play the fools, by authority.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: To play the fool by authority, is wisdom.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.p: Away with your mattery sentences, Momus; they are too grave, and wise, for this meeting.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Mercvry, give our jester a stool, let him sit by; and reach him of our cates.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Dost hear, mad Ivpiter? We will have it enacted; He, that speaks the first wise word, shall be made cuckold. What sayst thou? Is it not a good motion?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Deities, are you all agreed?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Agreed, great Ivpiter.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: I have read in a book, that to play the fool wisely, is high wisdom.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: How now, Vulcan! will you be the first wizard?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Take his wife, Mars, and make him cuckold, quickly.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Come, cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: No, let me alone with him, Ivpiter: I will make you take heed, sir, while you live again; if there be twelve in a company, that you be not the wisest of them.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: No more, I will not indeed, wife, hereafter; I will be here: mum.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Fill us a bowl of nectar, Ganymede: we will drink to our daughter Venvs.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Look to your wife, Vulcan: Ivpiter begins to court her.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Nay, let Mars look to it: Vulcan must do, as Venvs doe's, bear.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
Ovid.
sp.p: Here, daughter Venvs, I drink to thee.

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Thank you, good father Ivpiter.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Why, mother Ivno! gods and fiends! what, wilt thou suffer this ocular temptation?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Mars is enraged, he looks big, and begins to strut, for anger.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Well played, Captain Mars.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Well said, minstrel Momvs: I must put you in? must I? When will you be in good fooling of yourself, fiddler? never?

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: O, it is our fashion, to be silent, when there is a better fool in place, ever.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Thank you, rascal.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Fill to our daughter Venvs, Ganymede, who fills her father with affection.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.p: Wilt thou be ranging, Ivpiter, before my face?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Why not, Ivno? why should Ivpiter stand in awe of thy face, Ivno?

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.p: Because it is thy wives face, Ivpiter.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
Ivli.
sp.p: I will find fault with thee, King cuckold-maker: what, shall the King of gods turn the King of good fellows, and have no fellow in wickedness? This makes our poets, that know our profaneness, live as profane, as we: By my god-head, Ivpiter; I will join with all the other gods, here; bind thee hand and foot; throw thee down into earth; and make a poor poet of thee, if thou abuse me thus.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A good smart tongued Goddess; a right Ivno.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Ivno, we will cudgel thee, Ivno: we told thee so yesterday, when thou wert jealous of us, for Thetis.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Nay, today she had me in inquisition too.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Well said, my fine Phrygian fry, inform, inform. Give me some wine (King of Heralds ) I may drink to my cockatrice.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: No more, Ganymede, we will cudgel thee, Ivno: by Styx, we will.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.p: Aye, it is well, Gods may grow impudent in iniquity, and they must not be told of it---

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Yea, we will knock our chin against our breast, and shake thee out of Olympus, into an oyster boat, for thy scolding.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.p: Your nose is not long enough to do it, Ivpiter, if all thy strumpets, thou hast among the stars, took thy part. And there is never a star in thy fore-head, but shall be a horn, if thou persist to abuse me.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: A good jest, i'faith.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: We tell thee, thou angerest us, cot-quean; and we will thunder thee in pieces, for thy cotqueanity.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Another good jest.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: O, my hammers, and my Cyclops! this boy fills not wine enough, to make us kind enough, to one another.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Nor thou hast not collied thy face enough, stinkard.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: I will ply the table with nectar and make them friends.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Heaven is like to have but a lame skinker, then.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: "Wine, and good livers, make true lovers: I will sentence them together. Here father, here mother, for shame, drink yourselves drunk, and forget this dissension: you two should cling together, before our faces, and give us example of unity.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: O, excellently spoken, Vulcan, on the sudden!

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Ivpiter, may do well to prefer his tongue to some office, for his eloquence.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: His tongue shall be gentleman usher to his wit, and still go before it.

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: An excellent fit office!

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Aye, and an excellent good jest, besides.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: What, have you hired Mercvry, to cry your jests you make?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Momvs, you are envious.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Why, you whoreson block-head, it is your only block of wit in fashion (now adays) to applaud other folks jests.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: True: with those that are not artificers themselves. Vulcan, you nod; and the mirth of the jest droops.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: He has filled nectar so long, till his brain swims in it.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: What, do we nod, fellow Gods? sound music, and let us startle our spirits with a song.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Do, Apollo: thou art a good musician.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: What says Ivpiter?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Ha? ha?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: A song.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Why, do, do, sing.

sp.speaker: Plav.
sp.p: Bacchvs, what say you?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Ceres?

sp.speaker: Plav.
sp.p: But, to this song?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Sing, for my part.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.p: Your belly weighs down your head, Bacchvs: here is a song toward.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Begin, Vulcan ---

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: What else? what else?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Say, Ivpiter ---

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Mercvry ---

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Aye, say, say---
sp.l: Wake, our mirth begins to die:
Quicken it with tunes, and wine:
Raise your notes, you are out: fie, fie,
This drowsiness is an ill sign.
We banish him the queer of Gods,
That droops again:
Then all are men,
For here is not one, but nods.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: I like not this sudden and general heaviness, amongst our Godheads: It is somewhat ominous. Apollo, command us louder music, and let Mercvry, and Momvs contend to please, and revive our senses.

div2.stage: Song.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.l: Then, in a free and lofty strain,
Our broken tunes we thus repair;

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.l: And we answer them again,
Running division on the panting air:

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: To celebrate this feast of sense,
As free from scandal, as offence.

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Here is beauty, for the eye;

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: For the ear, sweet melody;

sp.speaker: Herm.
sp.p: Ambrosiac odours, for the smell;

sp.speaker: Chris.
sp.p: Delicious nectar, for the taste;

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: For the touch, a ladies waist;
Which doth all the rest excel!

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.p: Aye: This hath waked us. Mercvry, our Herald; Go from ourself, the great God Ivpiter, to the great Emperor, Avgvstvs Caesar: And command him, from us (of whose bounty he hath received his sir-name, Avgvstvs) that for a thank offering to our beneficence, he presently sacrifice as a dish to this banquet, his beautiful and wanton daughter Ivlia. She is a cursed quean, tell him; and plays the scold behind his back: Therefore, let her be sacrificed. Command him this, Mercvry, in our high name of Ivpiter Altitonans.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.p:
Stay, feather-footed Mercvry, and tell Avgvstvs, from us, the great Ivno Satvrnia; if he think it hard to do, as Ivpiter
hath commanded him, and sacrifice his daughter, that he had better to do so ten times, than suffer her to love the well nosed poet, Ovid: whom he shall do well to whip, or cause to be whipped, about the capital, for soothing her, in her follies.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene VI.
Cæsar, Mecoenas, Horace, Lvpvs, Histrio, Minos, Lictors, Ovid, Gallvs, Tibvllvs, Tvcca, Crispinvs, Albivs, Hermogenes, Pyrgvs, Ivlia, Cytheris, Plavtia, Chloe.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.l: What sight is this? Mecoenas! Horace! say!
Have we our senses? Do we hear? and see?
Or, are these but imaginary objects
Drawn by our fantasy? Why speak you not?
Let us do sacrifice? Are they the Gods?
Reverence, amaze, and fury fight in me.
What? do they kneel? Nay, then I see it is true
I thought impossible: O, impious sight!
Let me divert mine eyes; the very thought
Averts my soul, with passion look not, man.
There is a panther, whose unnatural eyes
Will strike thee dead: turn then, and die on her
With her own death.

div2.stage: He offers to kill his daughter.

sp.speaker: Mecoe., Horace.
sp.p: What means imperial Caesar?

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.l: What, would you have me let the strumpet live,
That, for this pageant, earns so many deaths?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Boy, slink boy.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Pray Ivpiter, we be not followed by the sent, Master.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.p: Say, sir, what are you?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: I play Vulcan, sir.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.p: But, what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Albi.
sp.p: Your citizen, and jeweller, sir.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.p: And what are you, dame?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: I play Venvs, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.p: I ask not, what you play? but, what you are?

sp.speaker: Chlo.
sp.p: Your citizen, and jeweller's wife, sir.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.p: And you, good sir?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Your gentleman, parcel poet, sir.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.l: O, that profaned name!
And are these seemly company for thee,
Degenerate monster? all the rest I know,
And hate all knowledge, for their hateful sakes.
Are you, that first the deities inspired
With skill of their high natures, and their powers,
The first abusers of their useful light;
Profaning thus their dignities, in their forms:
And making them like you, but counterfeits?
O, who shall follow virtue, and embrace her,
When her false bosom is found naught but air?
And yet, of those embraces, centaurs spring,
That war with human peace, and poison men.
Who shall, with greater comforts, comprehend
Her unseen being, and her excellence;
When you, that teach, and should eternize her,
Live, as she were no law unto your lives:
Nor lived herself, but with your idle breaths?
If you think gods but feigned, and virtue painted,
Know, we sustain an actual residence;
And, with the title of an Emperor,
Retain his spirit, and imperial power:
By which (in imposition too remiss,
Licentious Naso, for thy violent wrong,
In soothing the declined affections
Of our base daughter) we exile thy feet
From all approach, to our imperial court,
On pain of death: and thy misgotten love
Commit to patronage of iron doors;
Since her soft-hearted sire cannot contain her.

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.p: O, good my lord; forgive: be like the Gods.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Let royal bounty (Caesar) mediate.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.l: There is no bounty to be showed to such,
As have no real goodness: Bounty is
A spice of virtue: and what virtuous act
Can take effect on them, that have no power
Of equal habitude to apprehend it,
But live in worship of that idol vice,
As if there were no virtue, but in shade
Of strong imagination, merely enforced?
This shows, their knowledge is mere ignorance;
Their far-fetched dignity of soul, a fancy;
And all their square pretext of gravity
A mere vain glory: hence, away with them.
I will prefer for knowledge, none, but such
As rule their lives by it, and can becalm
All sea of humour, with the marble trident
Of their strong spirits: Others fight below
With gnats, and shadows, others nothing know.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene VII.
Tvcca, Crispinvs, Pyrgvs, Horace, Mecoenas, Lvpvs, Histrio.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: What is become of my little punk, Venvs! and the polt-foot stinkard, her husband? ha?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: O, they are rid home in the coach, as fast as the wheels can run.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: God Ivpiter is banished, I hear: and his cockatrice, Ivno, locked up. 'sheart, and and all the poetry in Parnassus get me to be a player again, I will sell them my share for a sesterce. But this is humours, Horace, that goat-footed envious slave; he is turned fawn now, an informer, the rogue: it is he has betrayed us all. Did you not see him, with the Emperor, crouching?

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Well, follow me. Thou shalt libel, and I will cudgel the rascal. Boy, provide me a truncheon. Revenge shall gratulate him, tam Marti, quam Mercvrio.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Aye, but Master; take heed how you give this out, Horace is a man of the sword.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: It is true, in troth: they say, he is valiant.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Valiant? so is mine arse; gods, and fiends! I will blow him into air, when I meet him next: He dares not fight with a puck-fist.

sp.speaker: Pyrg.
sp.p: Master, here he comes.

div2.stage: Horace passes by.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
Cris.
sp.p: Do you hear, Captain? I will write nothing in it but innocence: because I may swear I am innocent.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Nay, why pursue you not the Emperor for your reward, now, Lvpvs?

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.l: Stay, Asinivs;
You, and your stager, and your band of Lictors:
I hope your service merits more respect,
Than thus, without a thanks, to be sent hence?

sp.speaker: Hist.
sp.p: Well, well, jest on, jest on.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Thou base unworthy groom.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Aye, Aye, it is good.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Was this the treason? this, the dangerous plot,
Thy clamorous tongue so bellowed through the court?
Hadst thou no other project to increase
Thy grace with Caesar, but this wolfish train;
To prey upon the life of innocent mirth,
And harmless pleasures, bred, of noble wit?
Away, I loathe thy presence: such as thou,
They are the moths, and scarabs of a state;
The bane of empires; and the dregs of courts;
Who (to endear themselves to any employment)
Care not, whose fame they blast; whose life they endanger:
And under a disguised, and cob-web masque
Of love, unto their sovereign, vomit forth
Their own prodigious malice; and pretending
To be the props, and columns of his safety,
The guards unto his person, and his peace,
Disturb it most, with their false lapwing-cries.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Good. Caesar shall know of this; believe it.

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.l: Caesar doth know it (wolf) and to his knowledge,
He will (I hope) reward your base endeavours.
"Princes that will but hear, or give access
"To such officious spies, can never be safe:
"They take in poison, with an open ear,
"And, free from danger, become slaves to fear.

div2.stage: Act IIII. Scene VIII.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Banished the court? Let me be banished life;
Since the chief end of life is there concluded:
Within the court, is all the kingdom bounded,
And as her sacred sphere doth comprehend
Ten thousand times so much, as so much place
In any part of all the empire else;
So everybody, moving in her sphere,
Contains ten thousand times as much in him,
As any other, her choice orb excludes.
As in a circle, a magician, then
Is safe, against the spirit, he excites;
But out of it, is subject to his rage,
And loseth all the virtue of his art:
So I, exiled the circle of the court,
Lose all the good gifts, that in it I joyed.
"No virtue currant is, but with her stamp:
"And no vice vicious, blanched with her white hand.
The court's the abstract of all Rome's desert;
And my dear Ivlia, the abstract of the court.
Methinks, now I come near her, I respire
Some air of that late comfort, I received:
And while the evening, with her modest vail,
Gives leave to such poor shadows as myself,
To steal abroad, I, like a heart-less ghost,
Without the living body of my love,
Will here walk, and attend her. For I know,
Not far from hence, she is imprisoned,
And hopes, of her strict guardian, to bribe
So much admittance, as to speak to me,
And cheer my fainting spirits, with her breath.

div2.stage:
Act IIII. Scene IX.
Ivlia, Ovid.
Shee appeareth aboue, as at her chamber window.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.l: Ovid? my love?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Here, heavenly Ivlia.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.l: Here? and not here? O, how that word doth play
With both our fortunes, differing, like ourselves,
Both one; and yet divided, as opposed?
I high, thou low? O, this our plight of place
Doubly presents the two lets of our love,
Local, and ceremonial height, and lowness:
Both ways, I am too high, and thou too low.
Our minds are even, yet: O, why should our bodies,
That are their slaves, be so without their rule?
I will cast myself down to thee; If I die,
I will ever live with thee: no height of birth,
Of place, of duty, or of cruel power,
Shall keep me from thee; should my father lock
This body up within a tomb of brass,
Yet I will be with thee. If the forms, I hold
Now in my soul, be made one substance with it;
That soul immortal; and the same it is now;
Death cannot raze the effects, she now retaineth:
And then, may she be anywhere she will.
The souls of parents rule not children's souls,
When death sets both in their dissolved estates;
Then is no child, nor father: then eternity
Frees all, from any temporal respect.
I come, my Ovid, take me in thine arms:
And let me breathe my soul into thy breast.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: O, stay, my love: the hopes thou dost conceive
Of thy quick death, and of thy future life,
Are not authentical. Thou choosest death,
So thou mightest joy thy love, in the other life.
But know (my princely love) when thou art dead,
Thou only must survive in perfect soul;
And in the soul, are no affections:
We power out our affections with our blood;
And with our bloods affections, fade our loves.
"No life hath love in such sweet state, as this;
"No essence is so dear to moody sense,
"As flesh, and blood; whose quintessence is sense.
"Beauty, composed of blood, and flesh, moves more,
"And is more plausible to blood, and flesh,
"Than spiritual beauty can be to the spirit.
Such apprehension, as we have in dreams
(When sleep, the bond of senses, locks them up)
Such shall we have, when death destroys them quite.
If love be then thy object, change not life;
Live high, and happy still: I still below,
Close with my fortunes, in thy height, shall joy.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.l: Ay me, that virtue, whose brave eagles wings
With every stroke, blow stars, in burning heaven;
Should like a swallow (preying toward storms)
Fly close to earth: and with an eager plume,
Pursue those objects, which none else can see,
But seem to all the world, the empty air.
Thus thou (poor Ovid) and all virtuous men
Must prey like swallows, on invisible food;
Pursuing flies, or nothing: and thus love,
And every worldly fancy, is transposed,
By worldly tyranny, to what plight it list.
O, father, since thou gavest me not my mind,
Strive not to rule it: Take, but what thou gavest
To thy disposure. Thy affections
Rule not in me; I must bear all my griefs,
Let me use all my pleasures: virtuous love
Was never scandal to a Goddess state.
But, he is inflexible! and, my dear love,
Thy life may chance be shortened, by the length
Of my unwilling speeches to depart.
Farewell, sweet life: though thou be yet exiled
The officious court, enjoy me amply, still:
My soul, in this my breath, enters thine ears,
And on this turrets floor, will I lie dead,
Till we may meet again. In this proud height,
I kneel beneath thee, in my prostrate love,
And kiss the happy sands, that kiss thy feet.
"Great Iove submits a sceptre, to a cell;
"And lovers, ere they part, will meet in hell.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Farewell, all company; and if I could
All light with thee: hells shade should hide my brows,
Till thy dear beauties beams redeemed my vows.

div2.stage: Shee calls him backe.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.l: Ovid, my love: alas, may we not stay
A little longer (thinkst thou) undiscerned?

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: For thine own good, fair Goddess, do not stay:
Who would engage a firmament of fires,
Shining in thee, for me, a falling star?
Be gone, sweet lifeblood: if I should discern
Thyself but touched, for my sake, I should die.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.l: I will be gone, then; and not heaven itself
Shall draw me back.

div2.stage: He calls her backe.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Yet Ivlia, if thou wilt,
A little longer, stay.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.l: I am content.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: O, mighty Ovid! what the sway of heaven
Could not retire, my breath hath turned back.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.l: Who shall go first, my love? my passionate eyes
Will not endure to see thee turn from me.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: If thou go first, my soul will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Ivli.
sp.l: Then we must stay.

sp.speaker: Ovid.
sp.l: Ay me, there is no stay
In amorous pleasures: if both stay, both die.
I hear thy father, hence, my deity.
Fear forgeth sounds in my deluded ears;
I did not hear him: I am mad with love.
There is no spirit, under heaven, that works
With such illusion: yet such witchcraft kill me,
Ere a sound mind, without it, save my life.
Here, on my knees, I worship the blessed place
That held my goddess; and the loving air,
That closed her body in his silken arms:
Vain Ovid! kneel not to the place, nor air;
She is in thy heart: rise then, and worship there.
"The truest wisdom silly men can have,
"Is dotage, on the follies of their flesh.

div2.stage:
Act V.
Scene I.
Cæsar, Mecoenas, Gallvs, Tibvllvs, Horace, Eqvites Ro.

sp.speaker: Caesa.
sp.l: We, that have conquered still, to save the conquered,
And loved to make inflictions feared, not felt;
Grieved to reprove, and joyful to reward,
More proud of reconcilement, than revenge,
Resume into the late state of our love,
Worthy Cornelivs Gallvs, and Tibvllvs:
You both are gentlemen, you, Cornelivs,
A soldier of renown; and the first provost,
That ever let our Roman eagles fly
On swarthy Ægypt, quarried with her spoils.
Yet (not to bear cold forms, nor men's out-terms,
Without the inward fires, and lives of men)
You both have vertues, shining through your shapes;
To show, your titles are not writ on posts,
Or hollow statues, which the best men are,
Without Promethean stuffings reached from heaven!
Sweet poesies sacred garlands crown your gentry:
Which is, of all the faculties on earth,
The most abstract, and perfect; if she be
True borne, and nursed with all the sciences.
She can so mold Rome, and her monuments,
Within the liquid marble of her lines,
That they shall stand fresh, and miraculous,
Even, when they mix with innovating dust;
In her sweet streams shall our brave Roman spirits
Chase, and swim after death, with their choice deeds
Shining on their white shoulders; and therein
Shall Tyber, and our famous rivers fall
With such attraction, that the ambitious line
Of the round world shall to her centre shrink,
To hear their music: And, for these high parts,
Caesar shall reverence the Pierian arts.

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.l: Your Majesty's high grace to poesy,
Shall stand against all the dull detractions
Of leaden souls; who (for the vain assumings
Of some, quite worthless of her sovereign wreaths)
Contain her worthiest prophets in contempt.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: Happy is Rome of all earths other states,
To have so true, and great a president,
For her inferior spirits to imitate,
As Caesar is; who addeth to the sun,
Influence, and lustre: in increasing thus
His inspirations, kindling fire in us.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Phoebvs himself shall kneel at Caesar's shrine,
And deck it with bay-garlands dewed with wine,
To quite the worship Caesar does to him:
Where other Princes, hoisted to their thrones
By fortunes passionate and disordered power,
Sit in their height, like clouds, before the sun,
Hindering his comforts; and (by their excess
Of cold in virtue, and cross heat in vice)
Thunder, and tempest, on those learned heads,
Whom Caesar with such honour doth advance.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: All human business fortune doth command
Without all order; and with her blind hand,
She, blind, bestows blind gifts: that still have nursed
They see not who, nor how, but still, the worst.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Caesar, for his rule, and for so much stuff
As fortune puts in his hand, shall dispose it
(As if his hand had eyes, and soul, in it)
With worth and judgment. "Hands, that part with gifts,
"Or will restrain their use, without desert;
"Or with a misery, numbed to vertues right,
"Work, as they had no soul to govern them,
"And quite reject her: serving their estates
"From human order. Whosoever can,
"And will not cherish virtue, is no man.

sp.speaker: Eqves.
sp.l: Virgil is now at hand, imperial Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Rome's honour is at hand then. Fetch a chair,
And set it on our right hand; where it is fit,
Rome's honour, and our own, should ever sit.
Now he is come out of Campania,
I doubt not, he hath finished all his Æneids,
Which, like another soul, I long to enjoy.
What think you three, of Virgil, gentlemen,
(That are of his profession, though ranked higher)
Or Horace, what sayst thou, that art the poorest,
And likeliest to envy, or to detract?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Caesar speaks after common men, in this,
To make a difference of me, for my poorness:
As if the filth of poverty sunk as deep
Into a knowing spirit, as the bane
Of riches doth, into an ignorant soul.
No, Caesar, they be pathless, moorish minds,
That being once made rotten with the dung
Of damned riches, ever after sink
Beneath the steps of any villainy.
But knowledge is the nectar, that keeps sweet
A perfect soul, even in this grave of sin;
And for my soul, it is as free, as Caesar's:
For, what I know is due, I will give to all.
"He that detracts, or envies virtuous merit,
"Is still the covetous, and the ignorant spirit.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Thanks, Horace, for thy free, and wholesome sharpness:
Which pleaseth Caesar more, than servile fawns.
"A flattered prince soon turns the prince of fools.
And for thy sake, we will put no difference more
Between the great, and good, for being poor.
Say then, loved Horace, thy true thought of Virgil.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: I judge him of a rectified spirit,
By many revolutions of discourse
(In his bright reasons influence) refined
From all the tartarous moods of common men;
Bearing the nature, and similitude
Of a right heavenly body: most severe
In fashion, and collection of himself,
And then as clear, and confident, as Iove.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.l: And yet so chaste, and tender is his ear,
In suffering any syllable to pass,
That, he thinks, may become the honoured name
Of issue to his so examined self;
That all the lasting fruits of his full merit
In his own poems, he doth still distaste:
As if his minds piece, which he strove to paint,
Could not with fleshly pencils have her right.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: But, to approve his works of sovereign worth,
This observation (methinks) more than serves:
And is not vulgar. That, which he hath writ,
Is with such judgment, laboured, and distilled
Through all the needful uses of our lives,
That could a man remember but his lines,
He should not touch at any serious point,
But he might breathe his spirit out of him.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: You mean, he might repeat part of his works,
As fit for any conference, he can use?

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: True, royal Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Worthily observed:
And a most worthy virtue in his works.
What thinks material Horace, of his learning?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: His learning labours not the school-like gloss,
That most consists in echoing words, and terms,
And soonest wins a man an empty name;
Nor any long, or far-fetched circumstance,
Wrapped in the curious generalities of arts:
But a direct, and analytic sum
Of all the worth and first effects of arts.
And for his poesy, it is so rammed with life,
That it shall gather strength of life, with being,
And live hereafter, more admired, than now.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: This one consent, in all your dooms of him,
And mutual loves of all your several merits,
Argues a truth of merit in you all.

div2.stage:
Act V. Scene II.
Cæsar, Virgil, Mecoenas, Gallvs, Tibvllvs, Horace, Eqvites Ro.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: See, here comes Virgil; we will rise and greet him:
Welcome to Caesar, Virgil. Caesar, and Virgil
Shall differ but in sound; to Caesar, Virgil
(Of his expressed greatness) shall be made
A second surname, and to Virgil, Caesar.
Where are thy famous Æneids? do us grace
To let us see, and surfeit on their sight.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Worthless they are of Caesar's gracious eyes,
If they were perfect; much more with their wants:
Which yet are more, than my time could supply.
And, could great Caesar's expectation
Be satisfied with any other service,
I would not show them.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Virgil is too modest;
Or seeks, in vain, to make our longings more.
Show them, sweet Virgil.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Then, in such due fear,
As fits presenters of great works, to Caesar,
I humbly show them.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Let us now behold
A human soul made visible in life;
And more refulgent in a senseless paper,
Than in the sensual complement of Kings.
Read, read, thyself, dear Virgil, let not me
Profane one accent, with an untuned tongue:
"Best matter, badly shown, shows worse, than bad.
See then, this chair, of purpose set for thee
To read thy poem in: refuse it not.
"Virtue, without presumption, place may take
"Above best Kings, whom only she should make.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: It will be thought a thing ridiculous
To present eyes, and to all future times
A gross untruth; that any poet (void
Of birth, or wealth, or temporal dignity)
Should, with decorum, transcend Caesar's chair.
"Poor virtue raised, high birth and wealth set under,
"Crosseth heavens courses, and makes worldlings wonder.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: The course of heaven, and fate itself, in this
Will Caesar cross; much more all worldly custom.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: "Custom, in course of honour, ever errs:
"And they are best, whom fortune least prefers.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Horace hath (but more strictly) spoke our thoughts.
The vast rude swing of general confluence
Is, in particular ends, exempt from sense:
And therefore reason (which in right should be
The special rector of all harmony)
Shall show we are a man, distinct by it,
From those, whom custom wrapteth in her press.
Ascend then, Virgil: and where first by chance
We here have turned thy book, do thou first read.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Great Caesar hath his will: I will ascend.
It were simple injury to his free hand,
That sweeps the cobwebs, from un-used virtue,
And makes her shine proportioned, to her worth,
To be more nice to entertain his grace;
Than he is choice, and liberal to afford it.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Gentlemen of our chamber, guard the doors,
And let none enter, peace. Begin, good Virgil.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Mean while, the skies began thunder; and in tail
Of that, fell pouring storms of sleet, and hail:
The Tyrian lords, and Trojan youth, each where
With Venvs Dardane nephew, now, in fear
Seek out for sever all shelter through the plain;
Whilst floods come rolling from the hills amain.
Dido a cave, The Trojan Prince the same
Lighted upon. There, earth, and heavens great dame,
That hath the charge of marriage, first gave sign
Unto this contract; fire, and air did shine,
As guilty of the match; and from the hill
The nymphs, with shriekings, do the region fill.
Here first began their bane; This day was ground
Of all their ills: For now, nor rumours sound,
Nor nice respect of state moves Dido aught;
Her love, no longer now, by stealth is sought:
She calls this wedlock, and with that fair name
Covers her fault. Forth-with the bruit, and fame,
Through all the greatest Lybian towns, is gone;
Fame, a fleet evil, then which is swifter none:
That moving grows, and flying gathers strength;
Little at first, and fearful; but at length
She dares attempt the skies, and stalking proud
With feet on ground, her head doth pierce a cloud!
This child, our parent earth, stirred up with spite
Of all the gods, brought forth; and, as some wright,
She was last sister of that Giant race,
That thought to scale Ioves court; right swift of pace,
And swifter, far, of wing: a monster vast,
And dreadful. Look, how many plumes are placed
On her huge corps, so many waking eyes
Stick underneath: and (which may stranger rise
In the report) as many tongues she bears,
As many mouths, as many listening ears.
Nightly, in midst of all the heaven, she flies,
And through the earths dark shadow, shrieking, cries;
Nor do her eyes once bend, to taste sweet sleep:
By day, on tops of houses, she doth keep,
Or on high towers; and doth thence affright
Cities, and towns of most conspicuous site.
As covetous she is of tales, and lies,
As prodigal of truth: This monster, &c.

div2.stage:
Act V. Scene III.
Lvpvs, Tvcca, Crispinvs, Demetrivs, Histrio, Lictors, Cæsar, Virgil, Mecoenas, Gallvs, Tibvllvs, Horace, Eqvites Ro.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Come, follow me, assist me, second me: where is the Emperor?

sp.speaker: Eqves 1.
sp.p: Sir, you must pardon us.

sp.speaker: Eqves 2.
sp.p: Caesar is private now, you may not enter.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Not enter? Charge them, upon their allegiance, crop-shin.

sp.speaker: Eqves 1.
sp.p: We have a charge to the contrary, sir.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.l: I pronounce you all traitors, horrible traitors:
What? do you know my affairs?
I have matter of danger, and state, to impart to Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: What noise is there? who is that names Caesar?

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: A friend to Caesar. One that for Caesar's good, would speak with Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Who is it? look, Cornelivs.

sp.speaker: Eqves 1.
sp.p: Asinivs Lvpvs.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: O, bid the turbulent informer hence;
We have no vacant ear, now, to receive
The unseasoned fruits of his officious tongue.

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.p: You must avoid him there.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p:
I conjure thee, as thou art Caesar, or respectest thine own safety; or the safety of the state, Caesar: Hear me, speak with me,
Caesar; it is no common business, I come about; but such as, being neglected, may concern the life of Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: The life of Caesar? Let him enter. Virgil, keep thy seat.

sp.speaker: Eqvites.
sp.p: Bear back there: whither will you? keep back.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: By thy leave good man usher: mend thy peruke, so.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Lay hold on Horace there; and on Mecoenas, Lictors. Romans, offer no rescue, upon your allegiance: Read, royal Caesar; I will tickle you, Satyr.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: He will, humours, he will: He will squeeze you, Poet puckfist.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: I will lop you off, for an unprofitable branch, you satirical varlet.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Aye, and Epaminondas your patron, here, with his flagon chain; Come, resign: Though it were your great grand-fathers, the law has made it mine now, sir. Look to him, my party-coloured rascals; look to him.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: What is this, Asinivs Lvpvs? I understand it not.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Not understand it? A libel, Caesar. A dangerous, seditious libel. A libel in picture.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: A libel?

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Aye, I found it in this Horace his study, in Mecoenas his house, here; I challenge the penalty of the laws against them.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Aye, and remember to beg their land betimes; before some of these hungry court-hounds sent it out.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Show it to Horace: Ask him, if he know it.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Know it? His hand is at it, Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Then it is no libel.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: It is the imperfect body of an emblem, Caesar, I began for Mecoenas.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.l: An emblem? right: That is greek for a libel.
Do but mark, how confident he is.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: A just man cannot fear, thou foolish Tribune;
Not, though the malice of traducing tongues,
The open vastness of a tyrannies ear,
The senseless rigour of the wrested laws,
Or the red eyes of strained authority
Should, in a point, meet all to take his life.
His innocence is armour against all these.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Innocence? O, impudence! Let me see, let me see. Is not here an Eagle? And is not that Eagle meant by Caesar? ha? Does not Caesar give the eagle? Answer me; what sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Hast thou any evasion, stinkard?

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Now he is turned dumb. I will tickle you, Satyr.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Pish. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Dost thou pish me? Give me my long-sword.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: With reverence to great Caesar, worthy Romans,
Observe but this ridiculous commentor:
The soul to my device, was in this distich.
Thus, oft, the base and ravenous multitude
Survive, to share the spoils of fortitude.
Which in this body, I have figured here,
A Vulture ---

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: A Vulture? Aye; now, it is a Vulture. O, abominable! monstrous! monstrous! has not your Vulture a beak? has it not legs? and talons? and wings? and feathers?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Touch him, old Buskins.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: And therefore must it be an Eagle?

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.p: Respect him not, good Horace: Say your device.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: A Vulture, and a Wolf ---

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: A Wolf? good. That is I; I am the wolf. My name is Lvpvs, I am meant by the wolf. On, on, a Vulture, and a Wolfe---

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: Preying upon the carcass of an Ass ---

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.l: An Ass? Good still: That is I, too. I am the ass.
You mean me by the asse---

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.p: Pray thee, leave braying then.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: If you will needs take it, I cannot with modesty give it from you.

sp.speaker: Mecoe.
sp.l: But, by that beast, the old Ægyptians
Were wont to figure in their hieroglyphics,
Patience, frugality, and fortitude;
For none of which, we can suspect you, Tribune.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Who was it, Lvpvs, that informed you first,
This should be meant by us? or was it your comment?

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: No, Caesar: A player gave me the first light of it, indeed.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Aye, an honest sycophant-like slave, and a politician, besides.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Where is that player?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: He is without, here.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Call him in.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Call in the player, there: Master Æsope, call him.

sp.speaker: Eqvites.
sp.p: Player? where is the player? Bear back: None, but the player, enter.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Yes: this gentleman, and his Achates must.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Pray you, master usher; we will stand close, here.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: It is a gentleman of quality, this; though he be somewhat out of clothes, I tell ye. Come Æsope: hast a bay leaf in thy mouth? Well said, be not out, stinkard. Thou shalt have a monopoly of playing, confirmed to thee and thy covey, under the Emperor's broad seal, for this service.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Is this he?

sp.speaker: Lvpv.
sp.p: Aye, Caesar: this is he.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: Let him be whipped. Lictors, go take him hence.
And Lvpvs, for your fierce credulity,
One fit him with a pair of larger ears:
It is Caesar's doom, and must not be revoked.
We hate, to have our court, and peace disturbed
With these quotidian clamours. See it done.

sp.speaker: Lvpv., Caesar., Caes.
sp.p: Gag him, we may have his silence.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Caesar hath done like Caesar. Fair, and just
Is his award, against these brainless creatures.
It is not the wholesome sharpe morality,
Or modest anger of a satiric spirit,
That hurts, or wounds the body of a state;
But the sinister application
Of the malicious, ignorant, and base
Interpreter: who will distort, and strain
The general scope and purpose of an author,
To his particular, and private spleen.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: We know it, our dear Virgil, and esteem it
A most dishonest practice, in that man,
Will seem too witty in another's work.
What would Cornelivs Gallvs, and Tibvllvs?
This while the rest whisper Caesar.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Nay, but as thou art a man, dost hear? a man of worship; and honourable: Hold, here, take thy chain again. Resume, mad Mecoenas. What? dost thou think, I meant to have kept it, bold boy? No; I did it but to fright thee, Aye, to try how thou wouldst take it. What? will I turn shark, upon my friends? or my friends friends? I scorn it with my three souls. Come, I love bully Horace, as well as thou dost, I: it is an honest hieroglyphic. Give me thy wrist, Helicon. Dost thou think, I will second ever a rhinoceros of them all, against thee? ha? or thy noble Hippocrene, here? I will turn stager first, and be whipped too: dost thou see, bully?

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: You have your will of Caesar: use it Romanes.
Virgil shall be your Prætor; and ourself
Will here sit by, spectator of your sports;
And think it no impeach of royalty.
Our care is now too much profaned (grave Maro)
With these distastes, to take thy sacred lines:
Put up thy book, till both the time and we
Be fitted with more hallowed circumstance
For the receiving so divine a work.
Proceed with your design.

sp.speaker: Mecoe., Gall., Tibv.
sp.p: Thanks, to great Caesar.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Tibvllvs, draw you the indictment then, whilst Horace arrests them, on the statute of Calumny: Mecoenas, and I, will take our places here. Lictors, assist him.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I am the worst accuser, under heaven.

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: Tut, you must do it: It will be noble mirth.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I take no knowledge, that they do malign me.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Aye, but the world takes knowledge.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Would the world knew,
How heartily I wish, a fool should hate me.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Body of Ivpiter! What? Will they arraign my brisk Poetaster, and his poor journeyman, ha? Would I were abroad skeldering for a drachma, so I were out of this labyrinth again: I do feele myself turn stinkard, already. But I must set the best face I have, upon it now: well said, my divine, deft Horace, bring the whoreson detracting slaves to the bar, do. Make them hold up their spread golls: I will give in evidence for thee, if thou wilt. Take courage, Crispinvs, would thy man had a clean band.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: What must we do, Captain?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Thou shalt see anon: Do not make division with thy legs, so.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: What is he, Horace?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I only know him for a motion, Caesar.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: I am one of thy Commanders, Caesar; A man of service, and action; My name is Pantilivs Tvcca: I have served in thy wars against Mark Antony, I.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Do you know him, Cornelivs?

sp.speaker: Gall.
sp.p: He is one, that hath had the mustering, or convoy of a company, now, and then: I never noted him by any other employment.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: We will observe him better.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Lictor, proclaim silence, in the court.

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: In the name of Caesar, silence.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Let the parties, the accuser, and the accused, present themselves.

sp.speaker: Lict.
sp.p: The accuser, and the accused; present yourselves in court.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Demetrivs. Here.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Read the indictment.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p:
Rvfvs Laberivs Crispinvs, and Demetrivs Fannivs, hold up your hands. You are, before this time, jointly and severally indicted, and here presently to be arraigned, upon the Statue of Calumny, or Lex Remmia (The one by the name of Rvfvs Laberivs Crispinvs, alias Crispinas, Poetaster, and plagiary: the other, by the name of Demetrivs Fannivs, play-dresser, and plagiary) That you (not having the fear of Phoebvs, or his shafts, before your eyes) contrary to the peace of our liege lord, Avgvstvs Caesar, his crown and dignity, and against the form of a Statute, in that case made, and provided; have most ignorantly, foolishly, and (more like yourselves) maliciously, gone about to deprave, and calumniate the person and writings of Qvintvs Horacivs Flaccvs, here present, poet, and priest to the Muses: and to that end have mutually conspired, and plotted, at sundry times, as by several means, and in sundry places, for the
better accomplishing your base and envious purpose; taxing him, falsely, of self-love, arrogancy, impudence, railing, filching by translation, etc. Of all which calumnies, and every of them, in manner and form aforesaid, what answer you? Are you guilty, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Not guilty, say.

sp.speaker: Cris. Demet.
sp.p: Not guilty.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: How will you be tried?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: By the Romane Gods, and the noblest Romanes.

sp.speaker: Cris., Demet.
sp.p: By the Romane Gods, and the noblest Romanes.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Here sits Mecoenas, and Cornelivs Gallvs:
Are you contented to be tried by these?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Aye, so the noble Captain may be joined with them in commission, say.

sp.speaker: Cris., Demet.
sp.p: Aye, so the noble Captain may be joined with them in commission.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: What says the plaintiff?

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.p: I am content.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Captain, then take your place.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Alas, my worshipful Prætor! it is more of thy gentleness, than of my deserving, I wuss. But, since it hath pleased the court to make choice of my wisdom, and gravity, come, my calumnious varlets: Let us hear you talk for yourselves, now, an hour or two. What can you say? Make a noise. Act, act.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Stay, turn, and take an oath first. You shall swear,
By thunder-darting Iove, the King of gods;
And by the Genius of Avgvstvs Caesar;
By your own white, and uncorrupted souls;
And the deep reverence of our Romane justice;
To judge this case, with truth and equity:
As bound by your religion, and your laws.
Now read the evidence: But first demand
Of either prisoner, if that writ be theirs.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Show this unto Crispinvs. Is it yours?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Say Aye: what? dost thou stand upon it, pimp? Do not deny thine own Minerva, thy Pallas, the issue of thy brain.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Yes, it is mine.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Show that unto Demetrivs. Is it yours?

sp.speaker: Deme.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: There is a father, will not deny his own bastard, now, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Read them aloud.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: Ramp up, my genius, be not retrograde:
But boldly nominate a spade, a spade.
What, shall thy lubrical and glibberie Muse
Live, as she were defunct, like punk in stews?

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: (Excellent!)

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: (Alas! That were no modern consequence,
To have cotburn all buskins frighted hence.
No, teach thy incubus to poetize;
And throw abroad thy spurious snotteries,
Upon that puffed up lump of barmy froth,

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: (Ah, ha!)

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: (Or clumsy chilblained judgment: that, with oath,
Magnificates his merit; and bespoils
The conscious time, with humorous foam, and brawls,
As if his organs of sense would crack
The sinews of my patience. Break his back,
O Poets all, and some: For now we list
Of strenuous vengeance to clutch the fist.

div2.stage: Subscri. Cris.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Aye marry, this was written like a Hercvles in poetry, now.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Excellently well threatened!

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: Aye, and as strangely worded, Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: We observe it.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.p: The other, now.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: This is a fellow of a good prodigal tongue too, this will do well.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: Our Muse is in mind for the untrussing a poet,
I slip by his name; for most men do know it:
A critic, that all the world be scumbers
With satirical humours, and lyrical numbers.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: (Art thou there, boy?)

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: (And for the most part, himself doth advance
With much self-love, and more arrogance.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: (Good again.)

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: And (but that I would not be thought a prater)
I could tell you, he were a translator.
I know the authors from whence he has stole,
And could trace him too, but that I understand them not full and whole.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: (That line is broke loose from all his fellows: chain him up shorter, do.)

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.l: (The best note I can give you to know him by,
Is, that he keeps gallants company;
Whom I would wish, in time should him fear,
Lest after they buy repentance too dear.

div2.stage: Subscri. Deme. Fan.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Well said. This carries palm with it.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: And why, thou motley gull? why should they fear?
When hast thou known us wrong, or tax a friend?
I dare thy malice, to betray it. Speak.
Now thou curlest up, thou poor, and nasty snake,
And shrinkest thy poisonous head into thy bosom:
Out viper, thou that eatest thy parents, hence.
Rather, such speckled creatures, as thyself,
Should be eschewed, and shunned: such, as will bite
And gnaw their absent friends, not cure their fame,
Catch at the loosest laughters, and affect
To be thought jesters, such, as can devise
Things never seen, or heard, to impair men's names,
And gratify their credulous adversaries,
Will carry tales, do basest offices,
Cherish divided fires, and still increase
New flames, out of old embers, will reveal
Each secret that is committed to their trust,
These be black slaves: Romans, take heed of these.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.l: Thou twangest right, little Horace, they be indeed:
A couple of chap fallen curs. Come, We of the bench,
Let us rise to the urn, and condemn them, quickly.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Before you go together (worthy Romans)
We are to tender our opinion;
And give you those instructions, that may add
Unto your even judgment in the cause:
Which thus we do commence. First you must know
That where there is a true and perfect merit,
There can be no dejection; and the scorn
Of humble baseness, oftentimes, so works
In a high soul upon the grosser spirit,
That to his bleared, and offended sense,
There seems a hideous fault blazed in the object;
When only the disease is in his eyes.
Here-hence it comes, our Horace now stands taxed
Of impudence, self-love, and arrogance,
By these, who share no merit in themselves;
And therefore, think his portion is as small.
For they, from their own guilt, assure their souls,
If they should confidently praise their works,
In them it would appear inflation:
Which, in a full, and well digested man,
Cannot receive that foul abusive name,
But the fair title of erection.
And, for his true use of translating men,
It still hath been a work of as much palm
In clearest judgments, as to invent, or make.
His sharpness, that is most excusable;
As being forced out of a suffering virtue,
Oppressed with the licence of the time:
And howsoever fools, or jerking pedants,
Players, or such like buffoon, barking wits,
May with their beggarly, and barren trash,
Tickle base vulgar ears, in their despite;
This (like Ioves thunder) shall their pride control,
"The honest Satyr hath the happiest soul.
sp.p: Now, Romans, you have heard our thoughts. With-draw, when you please.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: Remove the accused from the bar.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Who holds the urn to us? ha? Fear nothing: I will quit you, mine honest pitiful stinkards. I will do it.

sp.speaker: Cris.
sp.p: Captain, you shall eternally girt me to you, as I am generous.

sp.speaker: Tvcc.
sp.p: Go to.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Tibvllvs, let there be a case of vizards privately provided: we have found a subject to bestow them on.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
sp.p: It shall be done, Caesar.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.p: Here be words, Horace, able to bastinado a man's ears.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: Aye. Please it great Caesar, I have pills about me
(Mixed with the whitest kind of ellebore)
Would give him a light vomit; that should purge
His brain, and stomach of those tumorous heats:
Might I have leave to minister unto him.

sp.speaker: Caes.
sp.l: O! be his Æscvlapivs, gentle Horace;
You shall have leave, and he shall be your patient.
Virgil, use your authority, command him forth.

sp.speaker: Virg.
sp.l: Caesar is careful of your health, Crispinvs;
And hath himself chose a physician
To minister unto you: take his pills.

sp.speaker: Hora.
sp.l: They are somewhat bitter, sir, but very wholesome;
Take yet another, so: Stand by, they will work anon.

sp.speaker: Tibv.
